quote: You're worried.
With reason.
About Worf, or about Commander   Riker?
Both.       I think perhaps it is best to   be ignorant of certain elements   of the Klingon psyche.
Above, look out!
It's over.
The exercise is over.
At ease, Lieutenant!
Exit Holodeck.
You do this every day?
No -- usually my calisthenics are   more...    (he searches for the     right word, then     settles for)   ... intense, but those sessions   are too personal to be shared.
I'll bet they are.
Computer. Program complete --   save.
Coming Commander?
Right behind you.

Captain's log, Stardate 42193.6.   We are on a long reach toward the   Morgana Quadrant, a section of   the galaxy which has yet to be   visited by a manned Federation   vessel. We are using the time   to further detail the charts of   this region.
There it is again. An area of   "blackness."
It appears, then disappears, then   reappears. There is no   predictable pattern -- no sequence.
On screen.
There it is.
I can't see anything. Magnify   section two-eight-five.
There -- it looks like a "hole"   in space.
We're acquainted with the   "wormhole" phenomenon. This   appears quite different.
What do sensors indicate?
Nothing.
Nothing?
I'm sure you must mean it's empty   of matter, Mister Data. There   is always some energy form at   work...
Sir, our sensors are showing that   to be an absence of everything.   It is a void without matter or   energy of any kind.
Yet, this "hole" has a form, Data.   It has height, width...
Perhaps. Perhaps not.
That is hardly a scientific   observation, Commander.
Sir, the most elementary and   valuable statement in science...   the beginning of wisdom... is:   "I do not know."       I do not know what that is.
Captain, if this were any ordinary   kind of hole in space...       ... wouldn't we be able to see   what's behind it?
Counselor?
I can feel nothing from it, sir,   if that's what you're asking.
Data -- is there any record of any   occurrence even vaguely similar   to this?
"Similar" in even the slightest   way.
Accessing.       Negative. There is no record of   any Federation vessel encountering   anything remotely like this.
I believe we have time for a   closer look, Number One.
Concur.       Ensign, slow to one-half impulse.   Adjust course to intercept this...   this whatever it is.
Scanning and recording as we go.
Changing course to intercept in...   in twelve minutes, sir.
Let's send a probe into it.
Worf, prepare a scanner probe.   Let's see what's in there.
Close enough, Ensign. Hold this   position.
Aye, sir. Holding this position.
You may launch the probe when   ready, Mister Worf.
All the probe's systems are   functioning perfectly.
It's gone.
What happened, Data?
Unknown.
Recommend we go to a Yellow Alert,   sir.
Why?
Sorry, sir, it's...
Explain.
This starship operates best,   Mister Worf, when we all know what   is on each other's minds.
My thoughts... were of an old   Klingon legend of... of a gigantic   black space creature which was   said to devour entire vessels...
Devours vessels?
Sorry, Commander. I agree that   these are thoughts hardly worthy   of a trained and practical   security officer.
Launch another probe, Mister Worf.   This time a Class One with full   sensor array.
Launching, sir.
Happened even more quickly.
Recommend we fire a photon   torpedo, Captain.
Negative.
Captain, based on where the probes   disappeared... I have been able   to plot the outer boundaries.   I could move in closer.
Take us in, Mister Crusher.   Thrusters only.
Data?
Still no readings of any kind,   sir.
Number One?
I'll agree with Worf at this   point, sir. Let's be careful.
What's happened?
Data?
Whatever it was... or whatever   it is... we seem to be inside of   it.
Didn't that happen a bit suddenly,   sir?
All stations, report!
Captain's log, supplemental.   While exploring a strange area   in space without any form of   matter or energy...
... a total void, we have   unexpectedly seemed to enter it.   Apparently we moved past its   mysterious outer boundary.
All stations have reported,   Captain. There seems to be no   immediate threat to our ship or   crew.
In which case, let's hold position   for awhile, Number One. This is   worth studying.
Incredible. It's like looking   off into... infinity, sir.       Remember the course in ancient   history at Starfleet Academy?   Back to the time when men still   believed the Earth was flat?
And that the sun revolved around   the Earth...
And if a ship sailed too far out   into the ocean it would fall off   the edge of the world...
"Beyond this place there be   dragons."
Data -- how long to complete your   scans? Let's not stay any longer   than we have to.
Captain, we have no communications   outside of the void.
Confirm! We are now receiving   no signals of any kind.
Hello, Doctor. You've been   briefed on what's happened?
I've heard, Captain. But I don't   understand it.
I wish I could say I did.       Increase magnification by ten.
By one hundred!
I'm not a bridge officer, but   isn't this... "impossible," sir?
Increase by one thousand, Mister   Data.       By ten thousand.
(continuing; indicates     Data)   It does know how to do these   things, doesn't it?
Commander Data knows precisely   what he is doing.

Forgive me, Mister Data. I'm not   accustomed to working with... with   non-living devices that...    (stops, bites off her     words)   Forgive me again. Your service   record says that you are alive   and I must accept that.
Engineering!
Engineering, aye.
Lieutenant, are your systems   functioning?
Yes, sir. Wherever we are, sir,   it seems to have no effect on any   Engineering function.
Thank you, Lieutenant.
Data?
Difficult to make a judgment based   on the absence of information.
Speculate.
The obvious hypothesis is   equivocal. This void has a total   lack of dimension. Therefore by   any accepted standard it does not   exist, yet being within it denies   that conclusion.
Then maybe we've moved into   another dimension?
Could a lack of dimension be   another dimension in itself?
That's an interesting question.
For a later discussion. It's   time we got on with our mission,   Number One. Starfleet can send   out a science vessel to   investigate further. Let's move   back out of this.
Aye, sir.       Reverse our direction and set a   course for the Cornelian star   system. Warp two.
Reversing direction, sir.       Course laid in.
Engage.
Our engines have engaged, haven't   they, Ensign?
Aye, sir.
Everything all right up there,   Captain?
Are the engines operating   normally, Engineer?
Everything looks fine here, sir.
We're increasing to warp four,   Engineer.
We now show warp four, Captain.
We should be seeing stars by now,   Data. How far have we come?
Inertial guidance shows seven   parsecs traveled, Captain.
Ensign Crusher?
Confirm, sir. Exactly what my   readings say.
Engineering, transfer to bridge.
What's happening, sir? I thought   we should have broken clear.
We should have. We're on a   reverse course.
Full stop, helm.
Full stop, sir.
According to this we're well past   the point we entered the void.
Except that we are still in it,   sir.
Captain... if we dropped a   stationary beacon and navigated   straight away from it, we would   have a fixed point of reference   to confirm speed and distance.
Make it so, Data. Lock onto the   beacon, and keep it dead astern.
The beacon is in place, Captain.
Dead ahead. Impulse power.
The beacon is falling astern.
Engineering, report.
All systems normal, sir.
Prepare to increase to warp two.
Aye, sir.
Captain, we are receiving a signal   from dead ahead.
Maybe you've found the door out   of this.
We are closing on the new signal,   Captain.
Identify.
Captain, it is the stationary   beacon we just released.
We must have come full circle,   sir.
We couldn't have, sir. I've shown   us steadily moving away from that   beacon.
All stop; hold position again.
(indicating the     viewscreen)   Look.
Captain, sensors indicate a   disturbance in sector one-zero-   eight. Possibly a vessel.
Perhaps some answers at last.   On screen.
The ship is equipped with a   cloaking device.
Romulan!
It's closing.
Shields up. Go to Red Alert!
I'll be at my duty station in   Sickbay.
It's uncloaking.
Arm your photon torpedoes, Mister   Worf.
Hold for my orders.
There!
Direct hits, sir. Our shields   are weakening.
Warn them we'll return fire.
Transmitting.
They've armed another full spread,   sir.
Fire torpedoes.
That was too easy.
Yes.
Captain, sensors can locate no   debris from the Romulan ship.
Captain, there is another vessel   approaching -- sector zero-nine-   one, mark, two-six.
Specifics.
On screen.
Magnify.
It's a Federation ship.       N-C-C... one-three-oh-five dash   E. It is the USS Yamato, our   sister ship.
The Yamato is nowhere near this   quadrant.
Open a hailing frequency, Data....
This is the USS Enterprise to...   USS Yamato. Respond, please...
This is the USS Enterprise calling   USS Yamato. Please respond on   this frequency.
No response, Captain.
Make a full scan.
Life support system -- engineering   and propulsion all seem   functional.    (turns; reacts at a     reading)   But there are no life signs over   there, sir.
Can we be getting a false   reading, Data?
Since we know nothing at all about   these circumstances, that is...   at least, conceivable, sir.
You look doubtful, sir.
I'm not anything right now, Number   One. I'm just a man looking for   answers.
Like the rat said -- "Keep the   cheese, I just want out of the   trap."
Captain, request permission to   board the Yamato with an away   team. There might be something   onboard -- in the logs -- which will   at least tell us what happened.
Granted. Minimum complement.
Worf. You're with me.

Captain's log, supplemental. We   remain like a fly in amber trapped   in the void. We have encountered   a vessel which appears to be the   USS Yamato. All its systems are   shown as functioning, yet it seems   devoid of life. Commander Riker   is leading an away team --   hopefully the answer lies over   there.
scene: 64   EXT. SPACE - THE ENTERPRISE AND THE USS YAMATO

quote: Do you have a lock on that other   ship?
Aye, sir. No problems at all.
Can you put us on the bridge?
Anywhere you say, Commander.
I am acquainted with the Yamato,   Commander. Recommend the Aft   Station of their bridge. When   in doubt, surprise them.
Them? Who's them?
Whoever may be there.
Sensors show no life signs.
Still, the tactic is sound.
Agreed.       Aft Station.
Aye, sir.
Phasers on stun, Lieutenant Worf.
(continuing; to     Transporter Chief)   Energize.
This isn't the bridge.
No -- don't fire.
I heard you screaming. I was   coming to help.
Help me? But I heard you cry out.
(touches his     communicator)   Transporter Chief, where do you   show us over here?
We show... as approximately...
Captain, do you read me?...
... having difficulties...
Number One, come in!
Transporter Room, this is the   captain. We are out of contact   with the away team. Beam them   back, immediately.
I have lost the lock on them.
Nothing on my communicator, sir.
Computer, on.
Let's find a turbolift to the   bridge.
Transporter Room -- have you been   able to establish a lock?
Initiate full check -- all   systems.
Engineering section, report. What   is our situation?

This isn't a Federation ship.   The walls are not tritanium...   close, but it's a material beyond   our technology.    (he then leads the way     to the turbolift)   Let's get to the bridge.   Somewhere there must be an answer   to all of this.
Wait -- if you go through there...   where will you be?
scene: B84	INT. USS YAMATO - MAIN BRIDGE

quote: On the bridge.
scene: B84	INT. USS YAMATO - MAIN BRIDGE

quote: But we are on the bridge.
scene: B84	INT. USS YAMATO - MAIN BRIDGE

quote: Should I continue?
scene: B84	INT. USS YAMATO - MAIN BRIDGE

quote: Yes -- move out. Let's see what   happens.
scene: B84	INT. USS YAMATO - MAIN BRIDGE

quote: Is it the same bridge?
scene: B84	INT. USS YAMATO - MAIN BRIDGE

quote: ... Or did we just step from one   bridge to another bridge?
scene: B84	INT. USS YAMATO - MAIN BRIDGE

quote: Captain! I have a star fix.
On screen.
It's an opening, sir.
Confirm, navigation is possible.
Should I set a course?
Transporter Room. Do you have   a fix on the away team?
Negative.
Commander.
scene: D84	INT. USS YAMATO BRIDGE - WORF

quote: At ease, Lieutenant! At EASE!
scene: D84	INT. USS YAMATO BRIDGE - WORF

quote: The star fix is fading.
Haskell, lock on to the Yamato   with the tractor beam. We leave   together.
I can't make the lock.
Captain. The star fix is fading.
Let it go, Data.
But, sir, we can get out.
Let it go.
Bridge, I've re-established   contact with the away team.
The Yamato's beginning to fade   out, Captain.
Come in, come in Enterprise.
Hold position, away team. I've   got you. We are bringing you   home!
Transporter Room, hurry!
Captain, it's almost gone.
What the hell's going on?
Are you all right, Number One?
Yes, but I've had it. Let's put   all this technology and computers   to work -- figure out what's going   on -- and get the hell out of   here.
A ship that was almost the Yamato,   existing in a "hole in space,"   no crew aboard -- what's the   purpose?
Add to it an attack by a   nonexistent Romulan vessel, it   does suggest an interesting   question: "Was our away team even   over there?"
If we weren't over there, where   the hell were we?
Captain, I have re-established   the star fix.
Great.
Set course -- velocity -- warp two.
Course and speed set.
Engage.
I have lost contact.
What?
The star fix is gone.
Sir, it is not in the same sector.   But another opening has appeared.
On screen.
Set a course for those stars.   Warp six.
Yes, sir -- warp six.
I have lost the signal.
Damn it.
All stop.
Captain...
I know Data, I can see it.
This game is now wearing very   thin.
Hold this position.       Counselor, you have said you   sensed no intelligence behind all   of this. You haven't changed in   that belief?
I'm not so certain of that now,   Captain. I do sense something   unusual about all this...
Perhaps a different level of   consciousness?
An intelligence so vast it eluded   me? Yes, perhaps.
Rats in a maze.
Exactly!
Explain.
Everything we've been through   reminds me of a laboratory   experiment. As though something   were testing our responses to   stimuli.
Are you suggesting we're in some   kind of laboratory?
Yes.
The opening seems closer,   Captain.
We're finished with being led   about this way.
Agreed, Captain. Hold present   position.
Good. Don't satisfy its   curiosity.
Why are you so alarmed when I've   gone to such trouble to look just   like you?
Return to your position,   Lieutenant.
Sir... ?
Captain, sensors show nothing out   there. Absolutely nothing.
It's a damned ugly nothing.
I am Captain Jean-Luc Picard of   the USS Enterprise.       ... representing a Federation of   planets in this part of the   galaxy.       Can you identify whoever or   whatever you are?
NAGILUM!
Speaks right out for something   your sensors say isn't there,   Data.
We've still no idea of what you   represent.
"Data."
Nagilum?
You are of different construction   than the others. Interesting.
Picard... Riker... Geordi...   Wesley...
What are you? Your construction   also differs.
My "construction"... ?
Perhaps referring to your gender.
Yes, I see...       There are minor differences. I   am what we call a "female."
I understand. The masculine and   the feminine.
It is the way in which we   propagate our species.
Please demonstrate how this is   accomplished.
Not likely.
Whatever you are, your actions   are not welcome.
Let me put up the shields, sir.
Our sensors do not show anything   there, Worf.
Your life-form surprises me more   and more. Is it also true that   you have only a limited existence?       Answer!
What information do you want?   I don't understand the question.
You exist -- and then you cease   to exist. Your minds call it   "death."
How interesting.
Sickbay?
It won't help. The body is   already cold.
We cannot allow you to do that!   We'll fight you...

(interrupting; VOICE     BOOMING)   To understand death, I must amass   information on every aspect of   it, every kind of dying. The   experiments shouldn't take more   than a third of your crew, maybe   half.
Captain's log, Stardate 42194.7.   It is obvious that whatever we   have met sees no value in our kind   of life-form. How do we fight   something that both is...
... and is not there?
I can sense this much. We are   unimportant to it.
In a battle for survival, Captain,   thirty to fifty percent   casualties...
... Would be appalling...
... But within acceptable limits.
This is not a battle, Lieutenant.
A "laboratory experiment" would   be the closest comparison.
Is there any reason for not   believing this Nagilum?
No.
All evidence indicates he is   willing and able to do what he   proposes.
Agreed. Under the circumstances   -- there is only one decision.   I will not stand by and watch   while half of my crew is   slaughtered.
Sir... I do not believe there is   anything you can do to prevent   it.
No. But I can control it.
How?
By destroying the Enterprise.
Isn't that like curing the disease   by killing the patient?
At least it's better than   standing by helplessly and dying.
Why do I feel this may not have   been the best time to join this   ship? I'll be in Sickbay if I'm   needed.
I will be at my station, Captain.
Recognize Picard... Jean-Luc...
Recognize Riker... William T.
Initiate auto-destruct sequence.
Does Riker... William T. concur?
I do. Initiate auto-destruct   sequence.
What is the desired time interval?
Stand by.       Interesting question. How long   to prepare to die?
Which is the least painful to our   crew? Move to it quickly? Or   take time to prepare for it   thoroughly?
Hell, twenty minutes sounds like   a nice round figure. Can we do   that?
The latest program allows it.
Initiate auto-destruct in twenty   minutes.
Twenty minutes to auto-destruct,   mark.
Nineteen minutes, fifty seconds...
Come.
Our destroying ourselves won't   change its mind. I could feel   that.
You didn't mention you were that   certain.
I was wrong not to tell you,   Captain. And your decision may   also be wrong.
Yes? Come in, please.
I have a question, sir.       What is death?
You've picked probably the most   difficult of all questions, Data.

Some explain it by inventing   gods wearing their own form...   and argue that the purpose of the   entire universe is to maintain   themselves in their present form   in an Earth-like garden which   will give them pleasure through   all eternity. And at the other   extreme, assuming that is an   "extreme," are those who prefer   the idea of our blinking into   nothingness with all our   experiences, hopes and dreams only   an illusion.
Which do you believe?

Considering the marvelous   complexity of our universe, its   clockwork perfection, its balances   of this against that... matter,   energy, gravitation, time,   dimension, pattern, I believe   our existence must mean more than   a meaningless illusion. I prefer   to believe that my and your   existence goes beyond Euclidian   and other "practical" measuring   systems... and that, in ways   we cannot yet fathom, our   existence is part of a reality   beyond what we understand now   as reality.
We should not let ourselves die,   Jean-Luc!
I agree with her, Captain.
If only half of us live, I prefer   to take my chances on being one   that does.
Yes. It's wrong of you to force   us into this...
It is wrong...
Yes, this is very wrong. None   of you should be reacting like   this.
Computer, locate Commander Data.
Commander Data is on the bridge.
It's not going to work, Nagilum.
Captain, we are clear. We are   out of the void.
It's gone, Captain -- we can abort   the auto-destruct.
Hold, Number One.
But...
Hold.
Fifty seconds to auto-destruct.
Thirty seconds to auto-destruct.
Captain, we are clear of the   void. You may stop the   auto-destruct.
Data, on any heading -- warp six   -- now!
Captain.
I don't believe it, Number One.   It could still be part of the   illusion. Data, report.
All navigational systems confirm   -- we are at warp six -- on   course...
Ten seconds to auto-destruct.   Nine seconds. Eight seconds.   Seven seconds... Six seconds...
... to the Morgana Quadrant.
Five seconds. Four seconds...
Troi?
It's gone, Captain. I no longer   sense its presence.
Abort auto-destruct sequence.
Three seconds. Two seconds...   Riker, William T. Do you concur?
Yes! Absolutely! I do indeed   concur! Wholeheartedly!
A simple "yes" would have been   sufficient, Number One.
I didn't want there to be any   chance of a misunderstanding.
He sure held that bluff to the   last second.
What bluff?
Well, Nagilum... I hope you got   what you needed.
You have provided me with much   more than I needed...
Why did you release us? You   could have seen how we faced   death.
It wasn't necessary. I have   learned all I needed to know.   Would you like me to share some   of my conclusions?
I'm not interested.

Of course you are. You are too   inquisitive not to want to know.       You seem to find no tranquility   in anything. You struggle against   the inevitable. You thrive on   conflict. You are selfish, yet   you value loyalty. You are rash,   quick to judge, slow to change.   It's amazing you've survived.   Be that as it may -- as species,   we have no common ground. You   are too aggressive. Too hostile.   Too militant.
During this period, you too have   been evaluated. It would seem   we have at least one thing in   common.
Oh?
Curiosity.
The point is well taken, Captain.   Perhaps that is a trait we share.
Then perhaps we'll meet again.   But next time, it will be out   here among the stars.
Put us back on course, at warp   three.
Warp three, sir...
And Ensign -- let's give any holes   a wide berth.
